skill.name: lint-dotnet
skill.description: Run .NET architecture linter to check for MSBuild/CPM violations
skill.summary: Run .NET architecture linter to check for MSBuild/CPM violations
skill.author: ANcpLua

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing YAML frontmatter and markdown. It references an external bash script but does not contain executable code, network calls, or file access within the skill file itself.

content.value_statement: .NET projects often have inconsistent build patterns that cause maintenance problems. This skill runs an automated linter to check for MSBuild violations and Central Package Management issues before they cause problems in your codebase.
actual_capabilities: Check for hardcoded versions in Directory.Packages.props
Ensure Version.props is a symlink (not copied)
limitations: Only checks MSBuild/XML patterns in .props and .csproj files
Requires .NET project structure with standard layout
Does not validate package versions against NuGet feeds

best_practices: Run /lint-dotnet before committing .NET projects to catch architecture violations early
Use Central Package Management for all version references to ensure consistency
Keep Version.props as a symlink in consumer repositories, never copy it
anti_patterns: Hardcoding versions like Version="1.2.3" in Directory.Packages.props
Copying Version.props instead of symlinking it in downstream repositories

faq.question: What versions of .NET does this support?
faq.answer: This linter checks MSBuild patterns compatible with .NET Core 3.1+ and .NET 5+ projects.

faq.question: Does this linter modify files?
faq.answer: No. The linter only reads and reports violations. It does not automatically fix any issues.

faq.question: Can I integrate this into my CI pipeline?
faq.answer: Yes. The underlying script can be run from any CI system that supports bash and has .NET SDK installed.

faq.question: Does this send any data externally?
faq.answer: No. The linter runs entirely locally and only reads project files on your machine.

faq.question: Why are some rules marked with different letters?
faq.answer: Each rule targets a specific violation pattern. RULE_A, B, C, and G are currently implemented. More rules may be added.

faq.question: How is this different from dotnet format?
faq.answer: dotnet format styles code. This linter enforces architectural patterns like Central Package Management and version handling conventions.
